adjectives.description: purposive (comparative more purposive, superlative most purposive)

entries.meaning: Serving a particular purpose; adapted to a given purpose, especially through natural evolution. [from 19th c.]
examples: Irresistably it came to me again that beauty, far from being wasted, was purposive, that this purpose was of a redeeming kind, and that some one who was pleased co-operated with it for my personal benefit.

entries.meaning: Done or performed with a conscious purpose or intent. [from 19th c.]
examples: Synonyms: deliberate, intentional, purposeful; see also Thesaurus:intentional

entries.meaning: (psychology) Pertaining to purpose, as reflected in behaviour or mental activity. [from 19th c.]
examples: The question at once arises whether medieval thinkers really believed that what we now call inanimate objects were sentient and purposive.

entries.meaning: Pertaining to or demonstrating purpose. [from 19th c.]
examples: The world was generally agreed to be a purposive one, responsive to the wishes of its Creator […].

entries.meaning: Possessed of a firm purpose. [from 20th c.]
(grammar) Of a clause or conjunction: expressing purpose. [from 20th c.]
examples: Many scholars suggest that  […]  the increase in the use of the to-infinitive in Middle English took place at the expense of the bare infinitive (i.e. an infinitive without the marker to).  […]  due to the loss of verbal inflections, it became difficult to distinguish the infinitival form from other verbal forms. As a result  […]  to began to function as a mere marker of the infinitive, losing its original ‘purposive’ sense  […]
